questions.text: Which of the following is an example of physiological hyperplasia? (NEET PG 2016 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Physiological hyperplasia is a natural process where there is an increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ, occurring due to normal biological stimuli. Examples include the thickening of the endometrium during pregnancy to prepare for potential implantation, liver regeneration after partial resection to restore functional capacity, and breast enlargement during pregnancy to prepare for lactation. All these processes are driven by natural, physiological demands and hormonal changes, making each example correct under the definition of physiological hyperplasia.

 

Option A, B, C: Each of these options individually represents a correct example of physiological hyperplasia; however, none of them alone fully captures the range of examples provided by option D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological hyperplasia occurs naturally in response to hormonal changes or increased tissue demands, such as during pregnancy or after tissue loss, demonstrating the body's ability to adapt and regenerate.

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 41/2 hours

 

The window period for the administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in the case of an acute ischemic stroke is 4¬Ω hours from the onset of symptoms. This time frame is critical as rtPA is most effective when administered early, aiming to dissolve the blood clot and restore blood flow to the affected part of the brain, thus minimizing or reversing the damage caused by the stroke.

 

Indications:

 

  • After Clinical diagnosis of stroke established
  • If onset of symptoms to time of drug administration </= 4.5 hours
  • If age >/= 18 years
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory
  • Consent given by patient or surrogate

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Coma/stupor/ recent MI.
  • Major surgery in last 14 days/ GI bleeding in last 21 days/ minor stroke symptoms.
  • Rapidly improving symptoms.
  • Sustained BP > 185/110 mmHg despite treatment.
  • Platelets < 100,000; HCT < 25%; glucose < 50 or > 400 mg/dL.
  • Use of heparin within 48hrs and prolonged PTT or elevated INR.
  • Prior stroke or head injury within 3 months; prior intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4¬Ω hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

choices.text: Angiotensin II

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. NO (nitric oxide)

 

Explanation

 

Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by CGMP.

 

Hormone-receptor complex activates the enzymes of the cell and causes the formation of another substance called the second messenger or intracellular hormonal mediator.

 

Second messenger produces the effects of the hormone inside the cells. Protein hormones and the catecholamines act through second messenger. Most common second messenger is cyclic AMP.

 

NO activates guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger) which activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, that causes blood vessels to relax.

 

Cyclic GMP is synthesized from the nucleotide GTP using the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. Cyclic GMP serves as the second messenger for

 

  1. atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
  2. nitric oxide (NO)
  3. the response of the rods of the retina to light

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin: Incorrect because somatostatin typically acts through inhibition of adenylate cyclase, thus reducing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, not through cGMP.

 

Option B. Angiotensin II: Incorrect as angiotensin II primarily acts through the phosphatidylinositol signaling pathway and does not utilize cGMP as a second messenger.

 

Option C. ADH: Incorrect because antidiuretic hormone (ADH) primarily utilizes cAMP as its second messenger, particularly in its renal actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitric oxide (NO) uses cGMP as its second messenger to mediate vasodilation. NO activates guanylyl cyclase, increasing cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to vessel relaxation. This highlights cGMP's role in cardiovascular function and its importance in the regulation of blood pressure.

questions.text: Our physiology is designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitterness. Which of the substances listed below is accountable for causing this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaloids

 

Alkaloids binding to receptor √† activation of GPCR √† IP3/ DAG √† ‚Üëintracellular Ca2+ √†  secrete ATP which in turn excites sensory afferent fibers √†  bitter taste.

 

TASTE

 

 

 

 

Poison, alkaloids are bitter in taste.



Sweet    Sugars (e.g. glucose, sucrose), alcohols (e.g. ethanol), aspartame, aldehydes (like vanillin, cinnamaldehyde)
Sour    Acids (e.g. citric acid, lactic acid), H‚Å∫ ions
Salty    Sodium ions (Na‚Å∫), other metal salts like K‚Å∫ or Li‚Å∫ salts
Bitter    Alkaloids (e.g. quinine, caffeine), poisons, toxins
Umami    Glutamate (e.g. monosodium glutamate - MSG), some nucleotides (e.g. inosinate, guanylate)
 

 

  • Anterior 2/3rd ‚Üí Chorda Tympani ‚Üí 7th Nerve
  • Posterior 1/3rd ‚Üí 9th Nerve
  • Posterior most (pharynx & palate) ‚Üí 10th Nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Incorrect. Amino acids are not typically responsible for a bitter taste; they are usually associated with the umami taste.

 

Option C. Hydrogen ions: Incorrect. Hydrogen ions are responsible for the sour taste, not bitterness.

 

Option D. Aldehydes: Incorrect. Aldehydes are generally associated with sweet or fruity tastes, not bitterness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaloids are the substances responsible for causing a bitter taste, activating G-protein-coupled receptors and the IP3/DAG pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ and the excitation of sensory afferent fibers.

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of Cajal

 

Slow waves appear to be caused by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

Interstitial cells of Cajal form a network with each other and are interposed between the smooth muscle layers, with synaptic-like contacts to smooth muscle cells and undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that may generate slow wave activity.

 

The slow waves mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction. The slow waves by themselves do not cause muscle contraction except in the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myenteric neurons: Incorrect. Myenteric neurons are part of the enteric nervous system and play a role in regulating gut motility, but they do not generate slow waves.

 

Option B. Smooth muscle cells: Incorrect. Smooth muscle cells respond to slow waves but do not generate them.

 

Option D. Parasympathetic neurons: Incorrect. Parasympathetic neurons modulate gut activity through the autonomic nervous system but do not generate slow waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

questions.text: Which of the following systems exhibits a feedback gain of infinity in negative feedback mechanism? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood volume control by kidney

 

The regulation of blood volume by the kidney, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism. When blood volume decreases, the kidney responds by conserving water and producing concentrated urine to help increase blood volume. Conversely, when blood volume increases, the kidney excretes excess water to reduce blood volume. This process is regulated by hormones like aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and helps maintain the body's fluid balance within a relatively narrow range until the error becomes zero leading to infinite gain.

 

The feedback gain is designed to be adaptive and responsive, preventing extreme deviations but not amplifying them to infinity. The other options (B. Temperature control in hypothalamus and C. BP control by baroreceptors) also involve negative feedback mechanisms that aim to maintain stability, not infinite gain.

 

Negative feedback is a regulatory mechanism in which a system responds to a stimulus by producing an output that opposes the stimulus, thereby reducing the deviation from the desired set point. In such a system, the feedback gain refers to the strength of the feedback loop, or the degree to which the output is affected by changes in the input.   

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature control in hypothalamus: This system also uses negative feedback but does not achieve infinite gain. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by initiating responses that either dissipate heat (e.g., sweating) or conserve heat (e.g., shivering).

 

Option C. BP control by baroreceptors: Baroreceptors provide negative feedback for blood pressure control by adjusting heart rate and vessel diameter. While effective, this system does not have infinite gain.

 

Option D. incorrect Infinite gain is seen in the regulation of blood volume by the kidney, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism. it helps maintain the body's fluid balance within a relatively narrow range until the error becomes zero leading to infinite gain. be used to describe highly effective regulatory systems of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood volume control by the kidney exemplifies a highly effective negative feedback mechanism, theoretically approaching infinite gain by maintaining blood volume within a narrow range. While true infinite gain is not possible in biological systems, the kidneys' regulatory function is exceptionally efficient.

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. O positive

 

The agglutination test is a blood test used to determine an individual's blood type. In the case of O positive blood, the test involves mixing a sample of the person's blood with two different types of antibodies: anti-A and anti-B.

 

The person's blood cells do not agglutinate in the presence of either antibody, it indicates that the person's blood type is O positive. This means that the person's blood cells do not contain either the A or B antigen, but do contain the Rh factor antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in the B panel, indicating the absence of B antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: Incorrect as there is no agglutination in the A panel, indicating the absence of A antigens.

 

Option D. AB positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in both A and B panels, which would be required for AB blood type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A and anti-B antibodies and the presence of agglutination with anti-Rh antibodies confirms the blood group as O positive. This means the individual's red blood cells lack A and B antigens but contain the Rh factor.

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and diameter of D and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering, the flow is laminar through both the cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A? (INICETMAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 times

 

Flow through B will be 8 times more than the flow through A.

According to Poiseuille Hagen formula,

 

F= AP X œÄ/8 x 1/n x r/L

F= flow

AP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

–ü = viscosity

r-radius of the tube

L-length of the tube

Hence flow directly varies to the 4th power of radius and inversely varies to length.

 

Flow through B = (2r)4/2L = 2*2*2*2/ 2 = 16/2= 8 times

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (ùëü4r4) and inversely proportional to the length (ùêøL) of the vessel.

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

 

AG = (Sum of cation) - (Sum of anion)

 

AG = (Na - (HCO3 + CL))

 

AG = 137 ‚Äì 115 = 22 mmol/L

 

Note: Normal AG ~ 12

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which hormone is not responsible for intrauterine growth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Growth hormone

 

Explanation:


Growth hormone (GH) plays a crucial role in postnatal growth and development, but it is not significant during intrauterine (fetal) growth. During fetal development, the receptors for growth hormone are not sufficiently developed, which limits its ability to influence growth in utero. Instead, other hormones such as insulin, thyroxine, and insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) are critical for intrauterine growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: This hormone is essential for fetal growth as it promotes the storage of glucose and fats, providing energy for developing tissues.

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroid hormones, particularly thyroxine, are crucial for both physical growth and brain development during fetal life.

 

Option C. Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF): IGFs, particularly IGF-2 during fetal life (and IGF 1 in adult life), play a significant role in promoting cellular growth and development. IGFs are produced in response to fetal pituitary signals but are the main drivers of growth, not GH itself.

 

Educational Objective:


Growth hormone is not responsible for intrauterine growth due to the underdeveloped nature of its receptors in the fetus, making insulin, thyroxine, and IGFs the primary hormones for fetal growth.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation in a case of reversed ductus venosus flow? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Left umbilical vein

 

Explanation:

 

  • In cases of reversed ductus venosus flow (which can occur in conditions like cardiac dysfunction or increased right atrial pressure), the normal pathway of oxygenated blood is altered.
  • The left umbilical vein, which carries freshly oxygenated blood directly from the placenta, maintains the highest oxygen saturation (~80%) as it hasn't mixed with any systemic venous return yet.
  • When ductus venosus flow is reversed, instead of the normal forward flow into the IVC, blood is shunted preferentially into the portal circulation.
  • This reversal prevents the direct transfer of highly oxygenated blood to the IVC, making the umbilical vein the vessel with highest oxygen content.
  • The oxygen saturation in IVC drops significantly due to: 
    • Loss of direct oxygenated blood from ductus venosus
    • Increased mixing with systemic venous return
    • Potential congestion from right heart dysfunction

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. The right atrium receives mixed blood from both SVC and IVC, and in cases of reversed ductus venosus flow, it receives even less oxygenated blood than normal.

 

Option C. Portal vein: Incorrect. Although it receives more oxygenated blood than normal due to the reversed flow, it still has lower oxygen content than the umbilical vein due to mixing with portal venous blood.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: Incorrect. Without the direct input of oxygenated blood via the ductus venosus, the IVC carries predominantly systemic venous return with lower oxygen content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding how pathological changes in fetal circulation can alter normal oxygen distribution patterns. In reversed ductus venosus flow, the highest oxygen concentration shifts from the IVC to the umbilical vein, highlighting the importance of normal fetal shunts in maintaining proper oxygen delivery.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Optic tract

 

The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

 

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is a type of light reflex. The blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction on illumination, while the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction.

 

It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumors of the optic thalamus.

 

Homonymous hemianopia HH is characteristically seen in optic tract pathway

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve: Incorrect. A lesion in the optic nerve typically results in a loss of vision in the eye served by the affected nerve but does not produce hemianopic pupillary responses. Instead, it might lead to a direct pupillary defect (also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or Marcus Gunn pupil).

 

Option C. Optic radiation: Incorrect. Lesions in the optic radiation cause visual field deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia) but do not affect the pupillary light reflex because the optic radiations carry visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex and are not involved in the reflex arc of the pupil light reflex.

 

Option D. Optic chiasma: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing of nasal retinal fibers at this location. This type of lesion affects the visual fields of both eyes but does not specifically result in a hemianopic pupillary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lesion site for Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is the optic tract, which when damaged, leads to a characteristic pupillary response where the pupil does not react to light shown on the side of the retina corresponding to the damaged tract. This finding is indicative of a post-chiasmal visual pathway issue and is useful for localizing neurological damage in clinical assessments.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department following a suspected stroke. Upon assessment, it is noted that the patient is able to speak fluently, but the words uttered lack coherent meaning and lacks understanding. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Wernicke's aphasia

 

Explanation:


Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech that lacks coherent meaning. Patients with this condition can speak in long sentences with normal grammar, but their speech may include unnecessary or made-up words, making it difficult for others to understand.

 

This condition results from a lesion in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. In this scenario, the patient's ability to speak fluently yet produce nonsensical speech indicates a disruption in language comprehension, hallmark features of Wernicke's aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conduction aphasia: This type of aphasia is caused by a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's and Broca's areas. Patients with conduction aphasia have good comprehension and fluent speech but struggle with repetition and may make phonemic errors.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by difficulty in finding the correct words, particularly nouns and verbs. Patients can understand speech and have fluent and grammatically correct speech but have trouble naming objects.

 

Option D. Broca's aphasia: This type of aphasia results from a lesion in Broca's area, leading to non-fluent, halting speech with good comprehension. Patients with Broca's aphasia have difficulty forming complete sentences and may produce short, broken phrases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's aphasia is identified by fluent but nonsensical speech due to impaired language comprehension.

questions.text: In the motor homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precision of movements

 

Precision of movements has maximum representation in the motor homunculus.

 

In the sensory homunculus, the relative sizes of the cortical areas is proportional to the use of the part, the number of specialized sensory receptors and precision required by respective peripheral area of the body.

 

Some body parts like lips are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex followed by the face and thumb while the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low control and skilled movements: Incorrect, as areas requiring low control do not have extensive cortical representation.

 

Option B. More muscle fibres are present: Incorrect, as the size of representation in the motor homunculus is not based on the number of muscle fibers, but rather on the precision and complexity of movements.

 

Option D. Intensity of perception: Incorrect, as intensity of perception is related to sensory input and the sensory homunculus, not the motor homunculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The motor homunculus has maximum representation for body parts requiring precision of movements, reflecting the complexity and intricacy needed for fine motor control.

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

 

Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the options given above except the pituitary gland. The pituitary does not play a direct role in iodide transport or thyroid hormone synthesis, hence the absence of NIS.

 

The sodium/iodide cotransporter, also known as the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS) is a transmembrane glycoprotein, which transports two sodium cations (Na+) for each iodide anion (I‚àí) into the cell. NIS mediated uptake of iodide into follicular cells of the thyroid gland is the first step in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: The primary site of NIS expression, essential for thyroid hormone production.

 

Option B. Placenta: NIS is expressed to transport iodide to the fetus, crucial for fetal development.

 

Option D. Salivary gland: NIS facilitates iodide transport, although its precise role here is less clear.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is essential for iodide transport in various tissues. The NIS seen in:

 

  • Thyroid
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands
  • Certain cancers are derived from these tissues.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a cell is primarily determined by the distribution of ions across the cell membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions. Potassium ions (K+) play the most significant role in establishing the RMP. This is because the cell membrane is more permeable to K+ ions compared to other ions, and there is a higher concentration of K+ inside the cell than outside.

 

The movement of K+ out of the cell down its concentration gradient leads to a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside. This difference in charge across the membrane is what we refer to as the RMP. Other ions, such as sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl-), have some influence, but their impact is much less compared to K+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca2+: Calcium ions have a much smaller role in setting the RMP. They are more involved in processes like muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release rather than in establishing the RMP.

 

Option C. Na+: Sodium ions have a minimal direct role in determining the RMP under normal conditions because the cell membrane is much less permeable to Na+ at rest compared to K+. The Na+/K+ pump helps maintain the gradient of Na+ and K+, but Na+ itself does not significantly influence the RMP.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions can influence the RMP, but their effect is secondary to that of K+. Since the membrane is more permeable to K+, the RMP is predominantly a result of K+ distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolactin and growth hormone

 

The hypothalamus exerts inhibitory control on both prolactin and growth hormone:

 

  • Prolactin: Inhibition is mediated by Prolactin-Inhibiting Hormone (PIH), which is dopamine. Dopamine inhibits the secretion of prolactin by lactotropes in the anterior pituitary.
  • Growth Hormone: Inhibition is mediated by Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone (GHIH), also known as somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of growth hormone by somatotropes in the anterior pituitary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the hormone secreted by the zone of adrenal cortex shown by the arrow: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Androgens

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for secreting different types of hormones. The zones are as follows:

 

  1. Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which are crucial for regulating sodium and potassium balance and, consequently, blood pressure.
  2. Zona Fasciculata: This is the middle layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol, which are involved in the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, as well as in the body's response to stress.
  3. Zona Reticularis: This is the innermost layer of the adrenal cortex. It secretes androgens, such as dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), which are precursors to sex steroids.

 

In the provided image, the arrow points to the bottom layer of the adrenal cortex, which is the zona reticularis. Therefore, the hormone secreted by this zone is androgens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucocorticoid: These hormones are secreted by the zona fasciculata, the middle layer of the adrenal cortex, not by the zona reticularis.

 

Option B. Mineralocorticoid: These hormones are secreted by the zona glomerulosa, the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex, not by the zona reticularis.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is secreted by the adrenal medulla, not by the adrenal cortex. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines like adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), which are involved in the body's fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenal Cortex

  • Zona glomerulosa secretes Mineralocorticoids
  • Zona fasciculata secretes Glucocorticoid
  • Zona reticularis secretes Androgens

 

Adrenal Gland

  • Adrenal medulla secretes Epinephrine and Norepinephrine

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, if a person performs deep inspiration followed by normal expiration, which point would be reached? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inspiratory capacity

 

Explanation:

 

When a person performs deep inspiration followed by normal expiration, they are utilizing their inspiratory capacity (IC), which is:

  • Inspiratory capacity (IC) represents the maximum volume of air that can be inhaled from the resting expiratory level (normal end-expiratory level)
  • It includes:  
    • Tidal volume (TV)
    • Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)
  • The maneuver described (deep inspiration followed by normal expiration) specifically measures IC, not FVC, because: 
    • It doesn't involve forced expiration
    • Returns to normal end-expiratory level, not maximum expiration
    • Only utilizes the volume above resting expiratory level

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced vital capacity: Incorrect. FVC requires a forced maximal expiration after maximal inspiration, which isn't performed in this maneuver. Normal expiration won't reach FVC.

 

Option B. Expiratory reserve volume: Incorrect. ERV is measured by exhaling maximally after normal expiration. The described maneuver doesn't involve additional expiration below normal end-expiratory level.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. TLC includes residual volume, which can't be measured by spirometry alone. The described maneuver only measures volumes above normal end-expiratory level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that different breathing maneuvers measure different lung volumes and capacities. A deep inspiration followed by normal expiration specifically measures inspiratory capacity, distinguishing it from forced vital capacity which requires maximal forced expiration.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there is an increase in both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC). These changes occur due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, which are characteristic of COPD.

 

  • FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. This increases in COPD due to air trapping.
  • TLC (Total Lung Capacity): The maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. It may be increased or remain normal in COPD due to hyperinflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD, both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) increase due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation.

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated AŒ± and AŒ≤ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

The pressure-volume curve represents the relationship between the lung volumes and the transpulmonary pressures. Zero pressure in this context usually refers to the point where the pressure inside the lungs is equal to the atmospheric pressure, indicating a state of no net airflow. This point corresponds to the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation.

 

  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): It is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. This capacity includes the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and the residual volume (RV). FRC is an important measure because it represents the balance point between the elastic recoil forces of the lungs and the chest wall.

 

 

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 liters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

 

Option C: Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in during each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration, during quiet breathing.

 

Option D: Inspiratory reserve volume is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in addition to the tidal volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zero pressure in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation.

choices.text: Increased Fat content of the cells

questions.text: What is the definition of hypertrophy?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Increased in size of cells

 

Explanation:

 

Hypertrophy refers specifically to an increase in the size of existing cells without an increase in cell number. From Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, this is confirmed when discussing muscle adaptations: "Increased activity can lead to muscle cell hypertrophy, which allows for increase in contractile strength." The key characteristic of hypertrophy is the enlargement of individual cells, not their multiplication.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option a. Increased Fat content of the cells - This describes lipid accumulation within cells, which is a different cellular change unrelated to hypertrophy. Hypertrophy involves growth of functional cellular components, not fat storage.
  • Option c. Increase in number of cells  - This defines hyperplasia, not hypertrophy. Hyperplasia involves cell multiplication through division, whereas hypertrophy involves enlargement of existing cells.
  • Option d. None of the above - This is incorrect since option b correctly defines hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophy is the increase in cell size that enhances functional capacity without cell multiplication, as observed in skeletal muscle adaptation to increased workload.

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

choices.text: Divalent Metal Transporter 1
Divalent Metal Transporter 2

questions.text: What is the transporter of iron into enterocytes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Divalent Metal Transporter 1

 

Explanation

 

Iron uptake into enterocytes is primarily facilitated by the Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1), which actively transports ferrous iron (Fe2+) across the apical membrane of these cells. The process involves several steps:

 

  1. Reduction of Iron: Luminal non-heme iron, predominantly in the ferric (Fe3+) state, must first be reduced to ferrous (Fe2+) iron. This reduction is carried out by ferrireductases like b cytochromes and STEAP3.
  2. Transport via DMT1: Once reduced to Fe2+, iron is transported into the enterocytes through DMT1 located on the apical membrane.
  3. Exit from Enterocytes: After crossing into the enterocyte, Fe2+ destined for the circulation is exported across the basolateral membrane by Ferroportin. This export is coupled with the oxidation of Fe2+ back to Fe3+ by iron oxidases such as hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin 1: Incorrect as Ferroportin is responsible for the export of iron from enterocytes into the blood, not for iron uptake into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Hephaestin: Incorrect because hephaestin is involved in the oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ during iron export from enterocytes, not in the uptake.

 

Option D. Divalent Metal Transporter 2: Incorrect as DMT2 is not the primary transporter involved in the uptake of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the uptake of ferrous iron (Fe2+) into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen, functioning in conjunction with enzymes that reduce ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) iron.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100hz tuning fork)?(INICET 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency - 1/contraction period

 

Where the contraction period is the time taken from the end of latent period (Beginning of the upstroke) to maximum force of contraction(maximum height of upstroke i.e beginning of the downstroke).

 

In the given diagram, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means, the tracer (Waves shown below the main graph) recorded 100 waves per second, below the twitch graph.

 

Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

 

The formula used to calculate the tetanizing frequency is:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period

 

Substituting the values obtained:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / 0.05 sec = 20/sec

 

Therefore, the tetanizing frequency of the muscle is 20 per second.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum tetanizing frequency of a muscle is determined by the reciprocal of the contraction period.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventral group of neurons

 

Ventral respiratory group of neurons, are located on each side of medulla found in the nucleus ambigus rostrally and the nucleus retroambigus caudally.

 

The function of this neuronal group differs from dorsal group by -

 

  1. The neurons of the ventral respiratory group remain almost totally inactive during normal quiet respiration.
  2. Does not participate in the basic rhythmical oscillation that controls respiration
  3. When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, respiratory signals spill over into the ventral respiratory neurons from the basic oscillating mechanism of the dorsal respiratory area
  4. Electrical stimulation of a few of the neurons in the ventral group causes inspiration, whereas stimulation of others causes expiration. Therefore, these neurons contribute to both inspiration and expiration. They are especially important in providing the powerful expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration. Thus, this area operates more or less as an overdrive mechanism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required, especially during heavy exercise.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsal group of neurons: Incorrect because the DRG is mainly active during quiet breathing and primarily controls inspiration.

 

Option C. Pneumotaxic center: Incorrect as the pneumotaxic center primarily modulates the switch between inhalation and exhalation to control the rate and pattern of breathing, rather than directly causing forceful expiration.

 

Option D. Chemoreceptors: Incorrect because chemoreceptors detect changes in the chemical composition of the blood (like CO2 and O2 levels) and influence the respiratory centers indirectly rather than actively firing during respiratory movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons, particularly some subsets within this group, are actively involved in generating the neural signals required for forceful expiration, making them essential during increased respiratory demands such as during intense physical activity.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (‚ÜëPCO2) ‚Üí ‚Üë Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (‚ÜëPCO2 & ‚ÜìO2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)√† slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (‚ÜëPCO2, ‚ÜìO2, ‚ÜìpH) are present simultaneously ‚Üí not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (but in the question pH is Normal 7.35 ) on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (‚ÜëPCO2, ‚ÜìO2, ‚ÜìpH) are more severe √† the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

questions.text: EEG pattern given below is suggestive of which of the following diseases? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creutzfeldt- Jakob Disease

 

Periodic sharp wave complexes occurring every 1 second is usually seen in sporadic CJD.

 

Spongiform encephalopathy characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism.

 

**Startle myoclonus is very peculiar feature observed in CJD.

 

Signs on MRI:

 

  • Sporadic CJD: 80-90% - Cortical-Ribbon sign on MRI.
  • Variant CJD: Hockey-stick appearance on MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic encephalopathies show triphasic wave (Negative-positive-negative waves).

 

Option B. GTCS shows high voltage, spike wave discharges in all leads.

 

Option D. HSV show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge (PLED) arising from temporal lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is associated with distinct EEG findings that are crucial for its diagnosis. Understanding the typical EEG patterns along with clinical presentation and advanced imaging can aid in the early and accurate diagnosis of this rapidly progressive and fatal disease.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology/Dementia/chap 438/12420

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department after an RTA with thoracic trauma. Despite adequate fluid resuscitation, the patient shows persistent hypotension and decreased cardiac output. Chest X-ray shows widened mediastinum. What is the most probable cause of decreased cardiac output in this scenario? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased contractility of heart

 

This scenario presents a case of cardiac tamponade, likely due to aortic injury suggested by the widened mediastinum following thoracic trauma. Despite fluid resuscitation (which would correct preload), the patient remains hypotensive with decreased cardiac output.

In cardiac tamponade, blood accumulates in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and reducing its contractility. This mechanical compression impairs the heart's ability to contract effectively, leading to decreased stroke volume and cardiac output, even when preload is adequate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased preload: While decreased preload can cause reduced cardiac output, this option is incorrect here as the scenario specifically mentions adequate fluid resuscitation, which would have corrected any preload issues.

 

Option B. Increased preload: In cardiac tamponade, right atrial pressure (preload) may actually be elevated due to impaired filling, but this is not the primary mechanism of decreased cardiac output.

 

Option C. Increased stroke volume: This would result in increased cardiac output, which contradicts the clinical presentation. In cardiac tamponade, stroke volume is decreased due to impaired contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased cardiac output can result from various mechanisms is crucial. While the original question focused on preload reduction in hypovolemic shock, this version emphasizes how mechanical compression of the heart (as in cardiac tamponade) can impair contractility and reduce cardiac output, even when blood volume is adequate.

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

 

Explanation

 

Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.

 

Mechanism of enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex: Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.

 

Option B. Enterocolic Reflex: Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.

 

Option C. Gastroileal Reflex: Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.

 

Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Duodenal distension
  2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  3. Acidity of the chyme
  4. Osmolality of the chyme
  5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text: A patient presented in the ER with hypotension. On auscultation, dullness of heart sound and dilated neck veins was diagnosed, along with cardiac tamponade. Which of the following JVP findings is typically associated with cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent y descent

 

Explanation:


In cardiac tamponade, there is an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which impairs the filling of the heart chambers, particularly during diastole. This results in the characteristic absence of the y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform.

 

The y descent normally represents the rapid filling phase of the right atrium and right ventricle.

 

In cardiac tamponade, this filling is restricted, leading to a blunted or absent y descent.

 

Mnemonic "No ThankYou"  ‚Üí No/ Absence of the Y descent in cardiac Tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prominent x descent: This is typically seen in conditions with increased atrial relaxation and tricuspid regurgitation, but not in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Cannon a wave: This is associated with conditions involving atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block, where atrial contractions occur against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Option D. Absent a wave: The a wave is absent in atrial fibrillation, where there is no coordinated atrial contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic JVP finding is the absence of the y descent.

questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear

 

Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. Serous acinar cells are generally found in pancreas and the submandibular salivary glands.

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi complex is involved in the modification and packaging of secretory proteins into vesicles that can be transported to the apical surface of the cell for release into the ducts or glands. The supranuclear location of the Golgi complex in these cells allows for efficient transport of these vesicles to the apical surface for secretion.

 

In contrast, other organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, and rough endoplasmic reticulum are typically located in the basal or perinuclear regions of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal: Incorrect, as the basal region is typically where the nucleus and other organelles like mitochondria are located.

 

Option C. Adjacent to nucleus: Incorrect, while the Golgi apparatus is near the nucleus, it is specifically located above the nucleus in the supranuclear position in serous acinar cells.

 

Option D. Apical: Incorrect, as the Golgi apparatus itself is not located in the apical region, though it directs secretory vesicles to this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi apparatus is typically located in the supranuclear region, facilitating the modification and transport of secretory proteins for efficient secretion into the glandular ducts.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, plays a crucial role in regulating water balance in the body by concentrating urine. It acts primarily through the aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) channels located in the kidney's collecting ducts. Here is how ADH functions:

 

  1. Receptor Interaction: ADH binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membranes of cells in the late distal convoluted tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts of the kidney.
  2. Signal Transduction: The binding of ADH to these receptors activates the cyclic AMP (cAMP) pathway, leading to the activation of protein kinase A (PKA).
  3. Aquaporin-2 Mobilization: PKA then phosphorylates specific proteins that lead to the translocation of AQP-2 water channels from intracellular storage vesicles to the apical membrane of the kidney cells.
  4. Water Reabsorption: Once inserted into the membrane, AQP-2 channels allow water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid back into the bloodstream, thereby concentrating the urine.
  5. Regulation by ADH Levels: Chronic high levels of ADH enhance the synthesis of AQP-2 channels through increased gene transcription, while low levels lead to the internalization of these channels, reducing water reabsorption.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

In conditions such as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, there is a genetic mutation that affects the V2 receptors or the AQP-2 channels themselves, rendering the kidney tubules unresponsive to ADH. This results in the inability to concentrate urine and excessive urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aquaporin 1: Incorrect, as AQP-1 is primarily involved in passive water transport in other parts of the kidney and other tissues, not under the control of ADH.

 

Option C. Aquaporin 3 and Option D. Aquaporin 4: Both are incorrect as these aquaporins are located in the basolateral membrane of collecting duct cells and are involved in water transport but are not the primary channels through which ADH acts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADH specifically regulates the body's water balance by acting through aquaporin-2 channels in the kidney's collecting ducts, facilitating the reabsorption of water back into the bloodstream and thus concentrating the urine. This mechanism is crucial for maintaining proper hydration and electrolyte balance in the body.

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: Devices which are not used in colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

Explanation:

 

The tools shows is the Sahli's method for hemoglobin estimation, a type of colorimetric test.

 

RBC pipette: This device is specifically designed for counting red blood cells and is marked with a red bead. It is not used in hemoglobin estimation via the colorimetric method. The RBC pipette plays no role in this test, which is why it is the correct answer for the device that is not used in this process.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Comparator: This is used to compare the color intensity of the hemoglobin solution with standard color shades to estimate the hemoglobin concentration.

 

Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube: A crucial component of the Sahli's hemoglobinometer, this tube is marked for measuring hemoglobin concentration in percentage and grams per deciliter.

 

Option D. N/10 HCl: This reagent is used to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, which can then be measured using the colorimetric method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not used in the Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation, which employs a colorimetric test involving the hemoglobinometer tube, comparator, and N/10 HCl.

questions.text: Thiazide works on ________ in DCT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Na+ Cl- Cotransporter

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics act specifically on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+ Cl-) cotransporter, which is responsible for the reabsorption of sodium and chloride from the lumen of the DCT into the cells. This inhibition leads to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in diuresis (increased urine production).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ K+ 2Cl- Cotransporter: This cotransporter is located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not in the DCT. Therefore, thiazide diuretics do not act on this transporter.

 

Option B. ENaC Channels: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are found in the collecting duct (CD), not the DCT. Thiazide diuretics do not affect these channels.

 

Option D. Na+ H+ Antiport: This antiport mechanism is not the target of thiazide diuretics. They do not act on this transport system in the DCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+ Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride and resulting in diuresis.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described‚Äîstaggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign‚Äîare indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH (Growth Hormone)

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is known to increase during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. During stress, the body requires more energy, which can be facilitated by the metabolic effects of GH. Similarly, during starvation or hypoglycemia, GH levels rise to help mobilize fat stores and increase blood glucose levels.

 

Deep sleep, particularly the NREM stage 3 (previously referred to as stages 3 and 4), is a crucial time for the release of GH. This hormone plays a significant role in growth, cell repair, and metabolism, which are all essential processes that occur during deep sleep.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACTH: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is released in response to stress but not significantly during starvation or deep sleep. Its primary function is to stimulate the production of cortisol from the adrenal glands.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Cortisol is another hormone released in response to stress and can be elevated during periods of starvation. However, it does not increase during deep sleep, making it an incorrect answer for this question.

 

Option D. Prolactin: Prolactin is not associated with increases during stress or starvation. In fact, stress can decrease prolactin levels, particularly in nursing mothers. Prolactin levels do not significantly increase during deep sleep either.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep, especially during the NREM stage 3 of sleep.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic

 

Based on the given graph, that A has the highest filterability, followed by B and C, it is likely that A has a smaller size and/or a positive charge, making it easier to pass through the filtration membrane. Similarly, C is likely larger and/or negatively charged, leading to reduced filterability. Therefore, the answer would be: Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

 

Negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for the differential filtration of charged substances. The order of filterability observed in the graph suggests that A is polycationic, B is neutral, and C is polyanionic. This is because polycationic substances would be readily filtered due to their positive charge, while polyanionic substances would be repelled by the negatively charged barrier and exhibit low filterability. Neutral substances would fall somewhere in between, depending on their size and shape. The molecular size exclusion limit you mentioned (between 4-8 nm) is also important for determining which substances are able to be filtered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive tests shows highest sensitivity and specificity for detecting early stages of hepatic fibrosis in patients with Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhanced Liver Fibrosis (ELF) test

 

The Enhanced Liver Fibrosis (ELF) test is a highly sensitive and specific non-invasive test for detecting early stages of hepatic fibrosis, particularly in NAFLD patients. It combines three direct markers of fibrosis: hyaluronic acid (HA), procollagen III amino terminal peptide (PIIINP), and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase 1 (TIMP-1). The ELF test has demonstrated superior performance in early fibrosis detection compared to other non-invasive tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate aminotransferases/platelet ratio (APRI): While useful for advanced fibrosis, APRI has lower sensitivity for early fibrosis detection, particularly in NAFLD patients. It performs better in viral hepatitis.

 

Option B. Fibro test: Although it's a validated test for fibrosis detection, it has lower sensitivity for early-stage fibrosis in NAFLD compared to ELF. Its performance is better in viral hepatitis and later stages of fibrosis.

 

Option D. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: These individual markers lack the comprehensive assessment provided by panel tests like ELF. They have lower diagnostic accuracy when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that different non-invasive fibrosis tests have varying performance characteristics depending on the underlying liver disease and stage of fibrosis. The ELF test shows particular strength in early fibrosis detection in NAFLD patients, while other tests may perform better in different clinical scenarios or disease stages.

questions.text: Baroreceptors are associated with which vessel? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:


Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the walls of blood vessels that monitor blood pressure. The carotid sinus is a small dilation of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid into external and internal carotid branches. These baroreceptors are specifically located in the adventitial layer of the vessel wall within this dilation. They sense changes in arterial pressure and transmit this information via the carotid sinus nerve (branch of glossopharyngeal nerve) to the medulla.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. External carotid artery: Baroreceptors are not located in the external carotid artery. They are specifically found in the carotid sinus, which is a dilation at the beginning of the internal carotid artery.
  • Option c. Subclavian artery: No baroreceptors are documented in the subclavian artery. The main locations of baroreceptors are the carotid sinus and the aortic arch.
  • Option d. Brachiocephalic trunk: While this vessel branches off the aortic arch, it is not specifically identified as containing baroreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are primarily located in two key areas: the carotid sinus (a dilation of the internal carotid artery) and the aortic arch. These pressure sensors are crucial for the short-term regulation of blood pressure via the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man, post-MI, had the following lab values. Which of the following must be his treatment plan? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

 

LDL - 125mg/dl

 

HDL - 33mg/dl

 

TGL - 270mg/dl
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Post-MI patients require aggressive management to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events. The lab values indicate elevated LDL and triglycerides, along with low HDL. The treatment plan includes the use of high-intensity statin therapy, which is recommended to significantly lower LDL cholesterol as part of secondary prevention strategies in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Atorvastatin 80 mg falls under the category of high-intensity statins and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol significantly, which helps in reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosuvastatin + fenofibrate: This combination might be considered if there were specific concerns about triglyceride levels that could not be managed by statin therapy alone. However, the primary goal post-MI is to manage LDL levels aggressively with high-intensity statins.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate primarily targets triglycerides and would not be the first choice when the primary objective is to lower LDL cholesterol post-MI.

 

Option D. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: While rosuvastatin is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, a lower dose may not be sufficient for high-risk patients post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg, is essential in the management of patients after an MI to reduce the risk of subsequent cardiovascular events, regardless of initial cholesterol levels. This approach aligns with guidelines that emphasize aggressive LDL reduction in patients with established cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Nuclear signaling pathways are all except:( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rat proteins

 

Explanation

 

Rat proteins are not nuclear signaling pathways. Recombinant rat IN- is a bioactive protein used in cell culture applications.

 

Other Options:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways involve a variety of molecules and proteins that are involved in transmitting signals from the cell surface to the nucleus of the cell.

 

Option A. Caveolins are integral membrane proteins that are involved in the formation of caveolae, which are small invaginations in the plasma membrane that are involved in signal transduction.

 

Option B. NF-kB is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of genes involved in immune response, inflammation, and cell survival.

 

Option C. Importins are proteins that are involved in the transport of proteins into the nucleus of the cell. They bind to nuclear localization signals on proteins and facilitate their transport into the nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways are complex systems involving proteins that either directly regulate gene expression or facilitate the transport of molecules into the nucleus.

questions.text: Which is the most potent physiological stimulator of aldosterone secretion in a healthy individual? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angiotensin II

 

Angiotensin II is the most potent physiological stimulator of aldosterone secretion in healthy individuals. While hyperkalemia is also a powerful stimulator, under normal physiological conditions, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is the primary regulator of aldosterone secretion. Angiotensin II increases aldosterone synthesis and secretion through AT1 receptor activation in the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex.

 

Key points about Angiotensin II's role:

  • It can increase aldosterone secretion up to 20-fold
  • Acts through both acute (minutes) and chronic (hours to days) mechanisms
  • Responds to changes in blood pressure and volume status
  • Functions as part of the physiological RAAS cascade

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemia: While it's a potent direct stimulus for aldosterone secretion, it typically represents a pathological state rather than the primary physiological regulator. It serves more as an emergency mechanism.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Incorrect because high sodium levels actually suppress the RAAS system and therefore decrease aldosterone secretion.

 

Option D. ACTH: While ACTH can stimulate aldosterone secretion, its effect is relatively weak and short-lived compared to Angiotensin II. It plays a minor role in physiological aldosterone regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hierarchy of aldosterone secretion regulators: While multiple factors can stimulate aldosterone secretion, Angiotensin II is the primary physiological regulator in healthy individuals, with hyperkalemia serving as a powerful but typically pathological stimulus. This distinction is crucial for understanding both normal physiology and pathological states affecting the RAAS system.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least conduction velocity? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Postganglionic sympathetic fibers

 

Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, also known as type C fibers, are known for their small diameter and lack of myelin sheath, characteristics that contribute to their slow conduction velocity compared to other nerve fiber types. These fibers are involved in the sympathetic nervous system, carrying impulses from the autonomic ganglia to the target organs. The absence of myelin significantly reduces their conduction speed because myelin acts as an insulator that enhances the speed of nerve impulse conduction through saltatory conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic motor fibers: These fibers, typically myelinated and larger in diameter, conduct impulses much faster. They are involved in controlling voluntary muscle movements.

 

Option C. Pre-ganglionic autonomic fibers: Generally myelinated though smaller than somatic motor fibers, pre-ganglionic fibers also conduct impulses faster than postganglionic sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Touch and pressure fibers: These sensory fibers are usually myelinated and conduct impulses at high speeds, facilitating rapid response to sensory stimuli.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Conduction Velocity Factors: The speed at which a nerve fiber conducts an electrical impulse is influenced by its diameter and whether or not it is myelinated. Larger diameter and myelination both contribute to faster conduction velocities.
  • Type C Fibers: These are the smallest and slowest conducting fibers due to their lack of myelination. They typically transmit nociceptive (pain) and sympathetic autonomic signals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options given, postganglionic sympathetic fibers (Type C fibers) have the least conduction velocity due to their small diameter and lack of myelin, which make them slower in transmitting nerve impulses compared to myelinated fibers.

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration across the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. No transport protein is required.

 

2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion - It moves from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration with the help of glucose transporters. No energy is required.
